I was in Chicago last summer. I chanced upon a brewing encounter between city police and a small assortment of African Americans on a major street downtown. 
The way they looked at the police was quite telling. Lit with flashing blue, I could see the people looking at the police with a mixture or fear and rage. It's quite an unpleasant face they were making. 
Obviously the state of relations between CPD and its residents of color is in crisis. People are terrified of the police. At the same time, though, there was a stubborn defiance in them. They'd seen the police do terrible things. And they weren't just going away. Whatever the long list of demands and justifiable anger at the police response, it's time to bring Chiraq back under control. 
The city is too important to let the gangsta culture rule. Death rates are too high. Intervention is a must. With the scope of the crisis defined, we can understand the problem and begin to deal with it. 
Better yet, why don't we let the people police themselves? This can't be done without guns. Firearm ownership was severely restricted back in the 70's. 
Chicago is the most segregated large northern city in the U.S.. It's also a city where the black middle class grew, removed as they were from white-owned businesses. Drive through the south side and you'll see the upper middle class homes and wide avenues--there is money there. 
Go through some neighborhoods and you're in very dangerous places, on a par with Haiti or Sub-Saharan Africa. 
Let's let South side Chicagoans do what's right for their neighborhoods. Rolling back the gang influence takes a lot of work and overhandedness can backfire. By liberalizing firearm ownership, the good people of Chicago can keep gang-prone yongsters in line; killing some yes, but also insuring the safety of the majority, who are victims in a society that denies them their right to firearms.
